The rigorous operating condition of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) poses a substantial hurdle for the long-term stability of Pt-based alloy catalysts; thus, the development of Pt-alloy catalysts with unique morphologies is crucial for enhancing the stability of PEMFCs. In this study, we synthesized a novel PtCu nano-dendrite (PtCuND) catalyst through a facile, one-step solvothermal process. The sub-nanometer particles and nanopores within this catalyst facilitate enhanced mass transport. In PEM single-cell tests, the PtCuND catalyst displays high activity and robust stability, achieving a mass activity of 0.65 A mgPt –1. Notably, after accelerated durability tests, the mass activity and the voltage at 0.8 A cm–2 of PtCuND exhibits only minimal decreases of 18.5% and 9 mV, respectively. The combined experimental results and theoretical calculations conclusively illustrate the optimized adsorption of oxygen species and the impact of compressive strain on the catalyst surface. The enhanced durability can be attributed to the maintained nano-dendritic morphology and the strengthened interaction within the Pt-Cu bonds. This work not only enhances the stability of PEMFCs but also provides a robust foundation for the future scaling up of catalyst production, paving the way for widespread application in sustainable energy systems. Graphical Abstract The PtCu nano-dendrites synthesized via a facile solvothermal method exhibit excellent PEMFC activity and stability, owing to the surface compressive strain, enhanced Pt-Cu interactions, and preserved morphology, thus offering long-term use potential for sustainable energy applications. Keywords PtCu nano-dendrites Oxygen reduction reaction Enhanced stability Proton-exchange-membrane fuel cell Sustainable energy system 1 Introduction Access to clean, available, and reliable energy has been a foundation of continuous prosperity and economic progress worldwide since the inception of the industrial era [1]. Proton-exchange-membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), known for their high power output and environmentally friendly nature, are considered integral components of future sustainable energy systems [2–4]. The sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode within PEMFCs have a pronounced effect on their collective performance, making the catalytic activity a critical factor [5–7]. Simultaneously, from a cost perspective, catalyst stability might be a more critical performance indicator than activity. However, the Pt/C catalyst, while serving as the mainstream option, encounters issues in both activity and stability, thereby significantly hindering the widespread use of PEMFCs [8–10]. Therefore, the development of Pt-based catalysts that exhibit superior comprehensive performance, particularly stability, is crucial for the advancement of PEMFC technology. Current research trends have shifted toward increased stability, including the synthesis of intermetallic compounds [11–13]; the integration of Pt with single-atom carriers to form composites [14–16]; the alloying of Pt with select stable metals [17–19]; and the fabrication of catalysts featuring specialized architectures such as nanocages, nanowires, and nano-dendrites [9,20–23]; among which, catalysts with specialized architectures generally exhibit superior structural stability, demonstrating minimal structural alteration during ORR potential cycling, which can prevent the agglomeration and growth typically observed in Pt/C catalysts after long-term operation of PEMFCs, thereby maintaining excellent stability. However, the preparation process for such catalysts is often intricate and challenging, making large-scale production difficult to achieve. Accordingly, the design and development of a facile method to synthesize catalysts with high structural stability holds significant value. Considerable research efforts have focused on the development of advanced electrocatalysts, including strategies such as the surface modification of Pt/C catalysts [24–26]; the combination of Pt with various late transition metals (TMs, such as Co, Ni, and Fe) to form Pt-based alloys [11,27–32]; and the exploration of single-atom catalysts devoid of noble metals [33–37], etc. Pt-based alloy catalysts, in particular, have shown great promise for practical applications, offering a favorable balance of performance and cost-effectiveness. Previous studies have highlighted the advantageous effects of alloying Pt with TMs, which can induce surface strain to optimize the surface energy, thereby increasing the ORR activity of the catalysts [38–40]. Despite their high activity, the easy dissolution of these TMs in acidic environments leads to poor catalyst stability [41], which poses a significant challenge for their long-term effectiveness in PEMFC applications. In this context, the use of Cu, which is cost-effective and insoluble in acidic media, can significantly enhance its catalytic performance when it is alloyed with Pt [42,43]; more importantly, the incorporation of Cu into Pt represents an effective approach to increase the stability of catalysts. In this work, a series of Pt-Cu nano-dendrites (PtCuNDs) for PEMFCs were synthesized via a facile and one-step process. The particle size of the PtCuND is confined to the sub-nanometer scale (approximately 3 nm), and the nanoporous characteristic of the nano-dendritic structure effectively facilitates mass transport. The intrinsic catalytic activity is finely tuned at the atomic level by preparing PtCuND catalysts with varying Pt to Cu ratios. The experimental results and theoretical calculations reveal that the different compositions of the catalysts lead to different d-band centers, resulting in different O species adsorption energies, ultimately yielding the optimal activity of PtCuND (Pt77Cu23ND). Furthermore, the unique nano-dendritic morphology and the incorporation of Cu are critical for enhancing the stability of the catalyst, maintaining the structural integrity of the catalyst under potential cycles. In practical single-cell testing, the mass activity (MA) of Pt77Cu23ND reaches 0.65 A mgPt –1, and after accelerated durability tests, the MA exhibits an attenuation of 18.5%, and the voltage at 0.8 A cm–2 decreased by only 9 mV, thereby meeting the performance criteria set by the Department of Energy (DOE). These metrics of the PtCuND catalyst surpass those of most of the recently reported advanced PEMFC cathode catalysts in terms of stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, Pt ≥ 37.5 wt%), Copper acetate monohydrate (Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, 99%), Ethylene glycol (EG, AR), 1-hexadecyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (C16mimCl), and the carbon powders (XC-72) were purchased from Macklin. All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of PtCuNDs A mixture of 46.5 mg of H2PtCl6·6H2O, varying quantities of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, 30.9 mg of C16mimCl, 60 mg of carbon powders, and 20 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) was prepared in a three-necked flask and subjected to sonication for 0.5 h to achieve a homogeneous black solution. Subsequently, the flask containing the solution was placed in an oil bath at 160 °C under an argon atmosphere for 1 h. Upon completion of the heating step, the mixture was rapidly cooled to room temperature using an ice bath. The PtCuND catalyst was then isolated by repeated washing with ethanol and subsequent drying at 60 °C overnight. The Pt nano-dendrite (PtND) catalyst was prepared using the same procedure, with the exclusion of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was recorded by a Rigaku Smart Lab 9 kW Advance equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54060 Å) in 2θ ranging from 20° to 80°. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were characterized by a JEM-2100F with an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was performed on an FEI TITAN transmission electron microscope operated at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo escalab 250Xi instrument using Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) operated at 150 W. All XPS data in this work were calibrated by setting C 1s to 284.8 eV. The Pt loading of catalysts was measured by inductively-coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) operated on a Plasma Quant PQ9000 instrument. Data reduction, data analysis, and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) fitting were performed and analyzed with the Athena and Artemis programs of the Demeter data analysis packages that utilizes the FEFF6 program to fit the EXAFS data. The energy calibration of the sample was conducted through standard and Cu foil and Pt foil, which as a reference was simultaneously measured. A linear function was subtracted from the pre-edge region, then the edge jump was normalized using Athena software. The χ(k) data were isolated by subtracting a smooth, third-order polynomial approximating the absorption background of an isolated atom. The k3 -weighted χ(k) data were Fourier transformed after applying a HanFeng window function (Δk = 1.0). For EXAFS modeling, the global amplitude EXAFS (CN, R, σ2 and ΔE 0) were obtained by nonlinear fitting, with least-squares refinement, of the EXAFS equation to the Fourier-transformed data in R-space, using Artemis software, EXAFS of the Cu foil and Pt foil are fitted and the obtained amplitude reduction factor S02 value (0.830 and 0.801) was set in the EXAFS analysis to determine the coordination numbers (CNs) in the Cu–O, Cu–Cu, Cu–Pt and Pt–O, Pt–Cu, Pt–Pt scattering path in sample. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical characterization was performed on a three-electrode setup utilizing a Pine RDE and a Princeton electrochemical workstation. Graphite rod, KCl-saturated Ag/AgCl electrodes, and glassy carbon electrodes served as the counter, reference, and working electrodes, respectively. Catalyst ink was prepared by sonicating 3 mg of catalyst into a mixture of 1235 μL ethanol, 245 μL ultrapure water, and 20 μL 5 wt% Nafion solution to yield a homogeneous suspension. The working electrode was prepared by coating 10 μL catalyst ink onto the glassy carbon electrode. Following the deposition of the catalyst ink onto the glassy carbon electrode, the surface was activated to eliminate surface oxide and contaminants in an Ar-purged 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 solution, with a scan rate of 100 mV s–1 until a stable baseline was achieved. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were conducted at a sweep rate of 50 mV s–1 over the potential range of 0.05 to 1.05 V in an Ar-purged 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 solution. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 solution between 0.05 and 1.05 V at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1. The accelerated durability test (ADT) was carried out in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 solution within the voltage range of 0.6 to 1.0 V for 30000 cycles. Throughout this study, all potentials were referenced to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). 2.5 Single-cell measurements The catalyst ink was formulated by suspending the catalyst in a blend of isopropanol, water, and a 5 wt% Nafion solution (with an ionomer-to-catalyst ratio of 0.9). This ink was subsequently applied to a 4 cm2 gas diffusion layer (SGL 29BC) via an ultrasonic spraying device, resulting in the formation of a gas diffusion electrode (GDE). The anode GDE, cathode GDE, and membrane were then integrated into a membrane electrode assembly (MEA) through a hot-pressing process at 120 °C for 5 min. For the cathode, PtCuND and a commercial Pt/C (20 wt%, JM) were employed as catalysts, with a Pt loading of 0.2 mgPt cm–2. On the anode side, a commercial Pt/C (60 wt%) was utilized with a Pt loading of 0.1 mgPt cm–2. The H2-O2 polarization curves were tested at 80 °C, 100% relative humidity (RH), with a backpressure of 1.5 bar and a gas flow rate of 0.5 SLPM H2/0.5 SLPM O2 for the anode/cathode. The H2-air polarization curves were assessed at 80 °C, 100% RH, and 2.5 bar back pressure, with 0.5 L min–1 H2/2.0 L min–1 Air. The ADT was conducted through square wave cycling within the voltage range of 0.6 to 0.95 V for 30,000 cycles, with H2 (0.2 L min–1) at the anode and N2 (0.2 L min–1) at the cathode. 2.6 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The DFT calculations within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation were carried out to analysis the reaction mechanism. We have chosen the projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials to describe the ionic cores and take valence electrons into account using a plane wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV. The convergence criterion for electronic energy is set to 10−5, and the criterion for force is set to 0.05 eV Å−1. The 4 × 5 supercell of Pt was constructed as the simulation model. For the Cu doped Pt, corresponding numbers of Cu are used to replace the Pt atoms randomly. The free energy was calculated using the equation: G = E_DFT + E_ZPE – TS where E_DFT is the ground state energy calculated by DFT. The vibrational frequencies of adsorbed species were calculated to consider vibrational entropies (S vib) and zero-point energies (E_ZPE) in the Gibbs free energy within the harmonic approximations using the finite difference method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of PtCuNDs PtCuNDs were synthesized via a one-step solvothermal process directly within ethylene glycol, employing a combination of metal precursors, carbon, and surfactants (Fig. 1(a) . This strategy was utilized to examine the effects of various Pt-to-Cu ratios on the catalytic activity of the PtCuNDs. The mole fractions of Pt and Cu were denoted as Pt x Cu100–x ND, with x representing the mole fraction of Pt in the alloy. The specific ratios were determined via ICP-OES, and the results are summarized in Table S1. The PtCuNDs are labeled Pt89Cu11ND, Pt82Cu18ND, Pt77Cu23ND, Pt69Cu31ND, and Pt63Cu37ND, respectively, based on ICP-OES results. Using TEM, we first analyzed the morphology of Pt77Cu23ND (Fig. 1(b). The image reveals a nano-dendritic structure composed of sub-nanometer particles, which are uniformly dispersed within the carbon matrix. A statistical analysis of the particle size distribution for Pt77Cu23ND yields a mean particle size of 3.32 nm (the inset of Fig. 1(b). HAADF-STEM reveals that the multitude of particles comprising the nano-dendritic structure are not closely interconnected (Fig. 1(c) and Fig. S1), but rather are organized into a network of nanopores, which are conducive to efficient mass transport during the ORR process. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern reveals four clear diffraction circles (Fig. 1(d), which align with the (111), (200), (220), and (311) lattice planes typical of the face-centered cubic (fcc) arrangement in Pt77Cu23ND. The HAADF-STEM image at the atomic scale, along with an enlarged view, shows interatomic distances of 0.218 and 0.195 nm (Fig. 1(e), which are indicative of the (111) and (200) lattice planes in Pt77Cu23ND [44], respectively. Moreover, the lattice spacing of the (111) crystal plane within Pt77Cu23ND is notably smaller than that observed in pure Pt nano-dendrites (PtND) (0.222 nm, as shown in Fig. S2), indicating the existence of a considerable compressive strain effect resulting from the incorporation of Cu. PtND has a particle size of 3.30 nm (Fig. S2), and the incorporation of Cu does not lead to an increase in particle size. Elemental mappings verify the uniform distribution of Pt and Cu throughout the nano particles (Fig. 1(f). Additionally, the line scanning profile spanning a single nano-dendrite further confirms the coexistence of Pt and Cu (Fig. 1(g). Detailed information on other PtCuNDs with different Pt to Cu ratios can be found in Figs. S3–S6. The crystal structure of the PtCuNDs catalyst was characterized via XRD. The distinct fcc arrangement is detectable through the sharp peaks observed at the (111), (200), and (220) positions, as depicted in Fig. 2(a) . Notably, compared with those of standard Pt metal (04-0802), the XRD peaks of PtCuNDs exhibit a significant positive shift (Fig. 2(b), which indicates that lattice contraction resulting from the introduction of Cu atoms (consistent with the HAADF-STEM results) and the formation of a Pt-Cu alloy [45]. This observation also suggests that the peak shift magnitude increases with increasing Cu content, which agrees with the ICP-OES analysis. The electronic structure of PtCuNDs was probed through XPS, as shown in Fig. 2(c). The Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2 peaks, located at approximately 71.5 and 74.9 eV, respectively, are attributed to the metallic state of Pt (Pt0), which serves as the predominant valence state. Additionally, two distinct peaks are attributed to oxidized Pt (Pt2+). The variations in the positions of the Pt peaks can be attributed to the strain effects resulting from the varying Pt to Cu ratios, which contribute to the unique electronic structure of PtCuNDs. Furthermore, the Cu 2p XPS spectra indicate that Cu predominantly exists in a metallic state, which highlights the robust metallic nature of the Cu in the PtCuNDs (Fig. S7). Through X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy and EXAFS analysis, we thoroughly investigated the electron arrangements and local coordination environments of Pt and Cu (detailed findings are presented in (Figs. 2(d)–(h)), Figs. S8–S12, and Table S2,3). For XANES and EXAFS examinations, Pt77Cu23ND was selected as a sample, and Pt foil, PtO2, Cu foil, Cu2O, and CuO were used as references for comparison. The XANES spectrum of Pt77Cu23ND (Fig. 2(d) shows a lower intensity at the Pt L3 -edge than that of PtO2 and slightly higher than that of the Pt foil, suggesting the retention of a predominantly metallic state with evidence of charge transfer, which is consistent with the XPS results. Integrating the EXAFS spectra (Fig. 2(e) and the fitting results for the Pt L 3-edge of Pt77Cu23ND (Table S2), it is evident that the Pt-Cu bond is notably shorter at 2.66 Å than the Pt-Pt bonds in the Pt foil (2.77 Å) and in Pt77Cu23ND (2.75 Å). This significant contraction is attributed to the compressive strain effect within Pt77Cu23ND, which further confirms the formation of a Pt-Cu alloy. The Cu K-edge XANES spectra exhibit a slight shift of the white line towards the higher-energy region, which is indicative of electron transfer from Cu to Pt within the alloy structure [31]. Moreover, the pre-edge energy of Pt77Cu23ND is similar to that of Cu foil (Fig. 2(f), which suggests that the predominant valence state of Cu in Pt77Cu23ND is metallic. Consequently, the effective incorporation of Cu, known for its superior resistance to dissolution, enhances the stability of Pt77Cu23ND [42]. Furthermore, the EXAFS analysis at the Cu K-edge reveals a slight positive shift and a marked decrease in the EXAFS spectra for Pt77Cu23ND, compared with those of the Cu foil (Fig. 2(g), which is attributed to the formation of Pt-Cu bonds within the alloy structure [18]. By utilizing the EXAFS wavelet transform (WT) technique, which provides insights into both K-space and R-space, we conducted an analysis to investigate the coordination surroundings of Pt and Cu in Pt77Cu23ND (Fig. 2(h). The WT plots at the Pt L 3-edge for the Pt foil and Pt77Cu23ND reveal intensity maxima of approximately 8.6 Å–1, characteristic of Pt–Pt bonds. However, Pt77Cu23ND exhibits an additional intensity maximum at approximately 6.2 Å–1, attributed to Pt–Cu bonds, confirming the formation of the Pt-Cu alloy. Moreover, no noticeable intensity maximum is observed at 4.9 Å–1, which is typically associated with Pt-O bonds. The WT analysis at the Cu K-edge is presented in Fig. S13, where the intensity maximum for Pt77Cu23ND differs from that of the Cu foil and the other two Cu oxides, indicating the interaction between Pt and Cu. 3.2 ORR performance evaluation The ORR performance of PtCuNDs and the benchmark Pt/C was evaluated in HClO4. Fig. 3(a) displays the CV curves, revealing a significant positive shift in the peak potential of the reduction region for intermediate groups on the PtCuNDs surface relative to Pt/C, a shift that benefits the ORR [46]. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA), calculated from the CV profiles and summarized in Table S4, shows that Pt77Cu23ND has the highest value. The LSV curves of the PtCuNDs are shown in Fig. 3(b), indicating that these catalysts demonstrate an enhanced half-wave potential (E 1/2) relative to that of Pt/C. In particular, Pt77Cu23ND represents the most favorable E 1/2 (0.926 V), surpassing that of Pt/C (0.869 V) by 57 mV. The Tafel plots for these catalysts are presented in Fig. 3(c) and were used to investigate their kinetic characteristics. Notably, all the PtCuNDs exhibit slopes that are lower than those of Pt/C, suggesting enhanced charge transfer kinetics due to Cu incorporation, and Pt77Cu23ND has the lowest slope (74.3 dec mV–1). The mass activity (MA) and specific activity (SA) were quantitatively calculated at 0.9 V, as depicted in Figs. 3(d), 3(e), respectively. Compared with the other catalysts, Pt77Cu23ND has superior MA and SA values, reaching peaks of 0.837 A mgPt –1 and 1.466 mA cm–2, respectively. These metrics represent a 7.5-fold and 8.4-fold increase over those of the Pt/C catalyst (MA of 0.112 A mgPt –1 and SA of 0.175 mA cm–2). The ORR activity of PtND was also evaluated, revealing its enhanced activity over that of Pt/C (Fig. S14). The electron transfer numbers (n) and hydrogen peroxide yield (X H2O2) for all PtCuNDs and Pt/C catalysts were tested via a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE). The results are presented in Fig. 3(f) and Fig. S16, respectively. The n values for the PtCuNDs are approximately 4.0, indicating the four-electron pathway for H2O production during the ORR process. Additionally, the X H2O2 of the PtCuNDs is markedly lower than that of Pt/C, indicating more efficient conversion of oxygen to water without excessive H2O2 formation. The durability of Pt77Cu23ND and Pt/C was evaluated through ADT within the range of 0.6 to 1.0 V in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 for 30,000 cycles. The results are illustrated in Figs. 3(g), 3(h) and Fig. S17, which reveal that Pt77Cu23ND exhibits an almost unaltered LSV curve with a tiny decrease of 2 mV in E 1/2 (Fig. 3(g), whereas Pt/C results in a pronounced shift of 57 mV in E 1/2 (Fig. 3(h). The change in MA for the Pt77Cu23ND and Pt/C catalysts through ADT is detailed in Fig. 3(i). Pt77Cu23ND shows a slight decrease of 8.2% in MA, a much smaller decrease compared to the 75.9% reduction in Pt/C. Additionally, the ECSA loss of Pt77Cu23ND (24.4%) is much lower than that of Pt/C (32.8%, Fig. S17). These findings collectively reveal the exceptional stability of Pt77Cu23ND. The stability of PtND was also tested (Fig. S18), showing that the E 1/2 of PtND decreases only 7 mV after ADT and the MA exhibits only a 13.9% loss, both of which are lower than those for Pt/C, further proving that the nano-dendritic structure contributes to the excellent stability of the catalyst. The stability of PtND is slightly inferior to that of PtCuND, indicating that the introduction of Cu can further enhance the stability. 3.3 Structural evolution analysis before and after ADT To explore the mechanism underlying the exceptional stability of Pt77Cu23ND, a thorough structural characterization following ADT was conducted. Fig. 4(a) presents a TEM image of the nanostructure after ADT, revealing that the morphology of Pt77Cu23ND remains largely unchanged compared with its original state, with the particle size distribution exhibiting minimal growth (from 3.32 to 3.39 nm). HAADF-STEM analysis further confirms the maintenance of nanopores within Pt77Cu23ND (Fig. 4(b), thereby ensuring sustained mass transport efficiency throughout the ADT process. Fig. 4(c) and Fig. S19 show the elemental mappings of Pt77Cu23ND, demonstrating the uniform distribution of both Pt and Cu across the catalyst structure after ADT. These structural analyses collectively highlight the excellent structural robustness of the nano-dendritic architecture. Conversely, the morphology of Pt/C significantly changes throughout the ADT process (Figs. 4(d), 4(e). Notably, a substantial increase in the particle size is observed (from 2.38 to 4.49 nm, inset of Figs. 4(d), 4(e), followed by marked aggregation. Fig. 4(f) depicts a diagram of how the structure of Pt/C changes during ADT, offering a visual representation that enhances the understanding of the morphological transformations that occur before and after ADT. This instability in the Pt/C structure leads to a pronounced decline in its performance following ADT. To further demonstrate the structural stability of PtCuND, PtCu nanoparticles (PtCuNP) were prepared and subjected to ADT (Fig. S20). The stability of PtCuNP is observed to be inferior to that of PtCuND, with a loss of 28 mV in E 1/2, which is attributed to the local aggregation and particle growth of PtCuNP during the ADT process. However, the stability of PtCuNP is superior to that of Pt/C. This collectively indicates that the nano-dendritic structure and the incorporation of Cu can significantly enhance the stability. Moreover, we investigated the Pt dissolution dynamics of Pt77Cu23ND and Pt/C during ADT. The results demonstrate that the Pt content of Pt77Cu23ND experiences only a 0.75% loss (Fig. 4(g), which is notably lower than the 1.12% loss observed for Pt/C. This observation indicates that incorporating Cu can effectively prevent Pt dissolution. Additionally, the dissolution dynamic of Cu in Pt77Cu23ND was also investigated, and the result reveals only a 12.4% cumulative loss during ADT (Fig. S21), demonstrating its superior stability under operational potentials. XPS analysis of Pt77Cu23ND after ADT shows a slight Pt 4f peak shift (Fig. 4(h), indicating Cu leaching and Pt-rich surface formation, which enhances catalyst stability [14]. This observation is further supported by the CV curves, which present hydrogen adsorption/desorption and Pt oxide reduction peaks (Fig. 3(a) [47]. The vacancy formation energies (E v) for both surface Pt and Cu, which represent the energies needed to break and detach atoms from the surface, are calculated to further analyze the structural stability of Pt77Cu23ND (Fig. 4(i). Similarly, the E v value for pure Pt, having the same number of atoms as Pt77Cu23ND, was also calculated for comparison. The E v values of Pt and Cu on Pt77Cu23ND is 1.68 and 1.50 eV, respectively, which are higher than the value of 1.14 eV for pure Pt. This indicates the superior stability of Pt and Cu within the Pt77Cu23ND structure compared with that of pure Pt. In conclusion, the outstanding stability of Pt77Cu23ND is attributed to its distinctive morphology and enhanced Pt-Cu interactions, which collectively contribute to its sustained performance even following durability testing. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism investigation To delve into the catalytic mechanism of the PtCuNDs, DFT calculations were carried out via spherical models (Fig. 5(a) and Fig. S22), which were constructed by cutting the (111) planes of the PtCuNDs and pure Pt. The projected density of states (PDOS) and d-band centers for all PtCuNDs and pure Pt were calculated, as illustrated in Fig. 5(b). With increasing Cu content, the PDOS near the Fermi level progressively decreases, suggesting a reduction in the charge transfer capability [18]. Simultaneously, the d-band center shifts to lower energy levels as the Cu content rises (Fig. S23), leading to varying O species adsorption energies. Therefore, we calculated the oxygen adsorption energies (ΔE o) of PtCuNDs and Pt, and correlated them with MA, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The results indicate that the ΔE o values for all PtCuNDs are lower than those of Pt, and the trend of decreasing ΔE o is consistent with the negative shift in the d-band center (Fig. S24). In addition, the volcano-shaped correlation between MA and ΔE o demonstrates that Pt77Cu23ND possesses a moderate binding energy for oxygen intermediates, avoiding both excessive adsorption and insufficient activation, which leads to the optimal catalytic performance [48]. To elucidate the source of the improved ORR performance of Pt77Cu23ND, we constructed theoretical models of Pt77Cu23ND (111) and Pt (111) for comparative analysis (Figs. S25 and S26). Fig. 5(d) depicts the ORR mechanism on the Pt77Cu23ND (111) surface, focusing on the critical intermediates: OOH*, O*, and OH*. The Gibbs free energies for these intermediates on both Pt77Cu23ND (111) and Pt (111) were calculated at 0 and 1.23 V (Fig. 5(e) and Fig. S27). At a potential of 0 V, the Pt77Cu23ND (111) surface offers a better adsorption energy for O2 than does Pt (111). At a potential of 1.23 V, the transition from O* to OH* is identified as the rate-determining step, and Pt77Cu23ND (111) has a lower energy barrier of 0.77 eV than does Pt (111) at 1.13 eV, indicating a more efficient ORR pathway for Pt77Cu23ND. Furthermore, the differential charge densities of the OH* adsorbed system on the Pt (111) and Pt77Cu23ND (111) surfaces were examined (Figs. 5(f), 5(g)). Pt77Cu23ND (111) clearly has an increased charge density (the dashed line box in Fig. 5(g), suggesting that more electrons are transferred to OH*, thereby stabilizing it. This stabilization results in a reduction in the energy required for the transition from O* to OH*, in agreement with the Gibbs free energy trend. The compressive strain on the Pt77Cu23ND surface has been confirmed by experimental results and theoretical calculations (Fig. S28), which is also a reason for the optimized surface O species adsorption energy and the enhanced activity [32]. These results are sufficient to illustrate that the incorporation of an appropriate amount of Cu can maximize the increase in ORR activity. 3.5 Single-cell performance evaluation The performance of the Pt77Cu23ND catalyst was assessed through single-cell testing, employing a gas diffusion electrode (GDE) method to fabricate a membrane electrode assembly (MEA). Currently, the primary application focus of PEMFCs has shifted towards heavy-duty vehicles, where the operating voltage typically ranges from 0.6 to 0.8 V [49,50]; accordingly, we have focused on investigating the performance within this voltage range. The MEA utilizing Pt77Cu23ND as the cathode demonstrated remarkable performance under H2-O2 conditions (Fig. 6(a) , achieving a current density of 1.216 A cm–2 at the rated voltage (0.67 V), significantly surpassing the performance of Pt/C, which reaches only 0.878 A cm–2. At the beginning-of-life (BOL), the MA of Pt77Cu23ND at 0.9 ViR-free (H2-O2) reaches 0.65 A mgPt –1, which is a significant increase of approximately 1.5-fold and 3.1-fold compared with the U.S. DOE 2025 target of 0.44 A mgPt –1 and Pt/C (0.21 A mgPt –1), respectively. This high MA value demonstrates the excellent ORR performance of Pt77Cu23ND. Notably, the performance of PtND is comparable to that of Pt/C (Fig. 6(a). Similarly, under H2-air conditions, Pt77Cu23ND achieves a current density of 1.073 A cm–2 at 0.67 V (Fig. 6(b), far surpassing the Pt/C of 0.716 A cm–2. In the kinetically dominant region (0.8 V), the current density of Pt77Cu23ND under H2-air reaches 0.314 A cm–2, which significantly surpasses the 0.160 A cm–2 of Pt/C, and meets the DOE standard (> 0.3 A cm–2), demonstrating the excellent intrinsic activity of Pt77Cu23ND. The ADT was carried out on MEAs employing Pt77Cu23ND and Pt/C as cathode catalysts, and the results before and after ADT are presented in Figs. 6(c), 6(d), both of which clearly show that the degradation of Pt77Cu23ND is markedly lower than that of Pt/C. The ending-of-life (EOL) MA of Pt77Cu23ND is measured at 0.9 ViR-free, which is 0.53 A mgPt –1 (Fig. 6(e), indicating an 18.5% decrease from its original value and much lower than the MA loss of Pt/C (81.0%). This result exceeds the DOE 2025 durability target, which sets the MA loss threshold at less than 40%. Moreover, the EOL voltage drop for Pt77Cu23ND at 0.8 A cm–2 is 9 mV in H2-air (Fig. 6(f), which is significantly lower than the 93 mV observed for Pt/C and in line with the DOE 2025 durability target of less than 30 mV. Compared to recently reported catalysts in the literature, this study demonstrates superior performance in terms of the MA loss and the voltage drop at 0.8 A cm–2 (Fig. 6(g). Moreover, the current density at 0.8 and 0.67 V, and the peak power density under H2-air at both BOL and EOL for Pt77Cu23ND and Pt/C are summarized in Figs. S29–S31. Notably, the decay rates for these performance metrics in the Pt77Cu23ND catalyst are significantly lower than those observed for Pt/C. Further structural analysis was conducted on EOL Pt77Cu23ND, and it is found that Cu is still distributed on the surface of the catalyst (Fig. S32), further demonstrating the strong interaction between Pt and Cu. These findings discussed above collectively validate the successful development of the Pt77Cu23ND catalyst, which not only demonstrates high activity but also maintains superior stability, making it an ideal candidate for practical PEMFC applications. 4 Conclusions To address the challenge of the inadequate stability associated with commercial Pt/C catalysts, we synthesized a series of Pt-Cu catalysts with nano-dendritic architectures. The incorporation of nanopores within the nano-dendritic structure notably enhanced the mass transport efficiency within the reaction system. Furthermore, the introduction of Cu atoms at various concentrations allows for the precise tuning of the catalytic activity, ultimately resulting in Pt77Cu23ND with an optimal adsorption energy for oxygen intermediates. In a half-cell, the MA of Pt77Cu23ND achieves 0.837 A mgPt –1, which is approximately 7.5 times higher than that of Pt/C. After 30,000 cycles, E 1/2 and MA attenuate by only 2 mV and a loss of 8.2%, respectively. When tested in a PEM single-cell, Pt77Cu23ND maintains an MA of 0.65 A mgPt –1, with only 18.5% decay after 30000 cycles of ADT. The voltage at 0.8 A cm–2 also experiences a minimal drop of 9 mV. These performance indicators not only meet the DOE established benchmarks but also surpass those of most recently reported catalysts in terms of stability, which is attributable to the high retention of its nano-dendritic structure and its intricate composition. coredata.dc:description: The rigorous operating condition of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) poses a substantial hurdle for the long-term stability of Pt-based alloy catalysts; thus, the development of Pt-alloy catalysts with unique morphologies is crucial for enhancing the stability of PEMFCs. In this study, we synthesized a novel PtCu nano-dendrite (PtCuND) catalyst through a facile, one-step solvothermal process. The sub-nanometer particles and nanopores within this catalyst facilitate enhanced mass transport. In PEM single-cell tests, the PtCuND catalyst displays high activity and robust stability, achieving a mass activity of 0.65 A mgPt –1. Notably, after accelerated durability tests, the mass activity and the voltage at 0.8 A cm–2 of PtCuND exhibits only minimal decreases of 18.5% and 9 mV, respectively. The combined experimental results and theoretical calculations conclusively illustrate the optimized adsorption of oxygen species and the impact of compressive strain on the catalyst surface. The enhanced durability can be attributed to the maintained nano-dendritic morphology and the strengthened interaction within the Pt-Cu bonds. This work not only enhances the stability of PEMFCs but also provides a robust foundation for the future scaling up of catalyst production, paving the way for widespread application in sustainable energy systems.
